newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICA'S NUM SEEKS ACTION ON ALEXKOR SELL-OFF.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICA'S NUM SEEKS ACTION ON ALEXKOR SELL-OFF.

text.p: South Africa's National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) on Friday accused the Public Enterprises Ministry of indifference towards the privatisation of state diamond mining company Alexkor.
"The privatisation ought to have happened last year already," NUM General Secretary Kgalema Motlanthe told a news conference.

"It's ironic when the government complains it can't privatise (because of unions), but in the only case where they have a willing partner in labour and the community, there's dilly-dallying by the ministry," he said.
Motlanthe said the Public Enterprises Ministry was acting on advice from an official who often did not attend meetings of the Restructuring and Transformation Committee (RTC).

The RTC, charged with planning the restructuring and eventual privatisation of the company, said in a separate statement on Thursday that deadlock had been reached on corporate governance after a disagreement with the government.
It gave no further details, but said the issue had been referred to the Inter-ministerial Coordinating Committee. In the meantime, the RTC has suspended its operations.
The sale of up to 100 percent of the Namaqualand diamond mine is under consideration as part of the government's ongoing privatisation programme.
Motlanthe said the Alexkor privatisation was so far behind schedule that there was a suspicion that it was being deliberately run down so that it could be sold "for a song".
"Our view is that it's a resource. (But) there's real widespread theft on that mine. Diamonds are disappearing like there's no tomorrow," he said.

In a bid to jumpstart the privatisation, Motlanthe said the NUM would ask for assistance from a cluster of government ministries including finance, trade and industry, minerals and energy affairs and transport.
"We are going to be knocking on all those doors," he said.
